body:
Thanks @kami I reviewed the test case and I think it is working as expected. The Outscale driver maps valid Outscale regions to the Outscale hosts. It should not let arbitrary hosts. In this case, if you don't add any explicit valid region the Outscale driver works with the default region and it assigns the default host 'osu.eu-west-2.outscale.com'. The default region/host is the same for AWS2 and AWS4. It is the reason to see the same default host twice. You can have a look in this line https://github.com/apache/libcloud/blob/trunk/libcloud/storage/drivers/rgw.py#L116 Maybe it makes sense raising an expection when host is not none? Something similar to: 
   if region not in S3_RGW_OUTSCALE_HOSTS_BY_REGION:
      raise LibcloudError('Unknown region (%s)' % (region), driver=self)
   if host is not None:
      raise LibcloudError('This driver does not accept arbitrary host', driver=self)
   host = S3_RGW_OUTSCALE_HOSTS_BY_REGION[region]
@Kami  done :)
@jetbird Can you please test latest changes against the live provider API?
Thanks for explaining the fixes :) Of course, I will test it now.
@Kami Tested. It works fine for me :)

@jetbird Great :+1: 

It would also be good if you can add some basic docs for the driver and contact the provider (tall them about Libcloud, driver, etc. and ask them if it's possible to mention it somewhere on the page / docs, etc.).

open questions:
- The cloudstack documentation is quite handwave-y about POST [1]; probably because tomcat treats urlencoded POST requests transparently [2]. So I'm not sure if it makes sense to expose the HTTP verb to the user or if libcloud should just do The Right Thing automatically
- In `common.cloudstack.CloudStackConnection`, `_sync_request` and `_async_request` are basically treated like overrides of `request` and `async_request` but without actually using the same name (`_sync_request` even gets defined as `request_method`). Is this intended and just the names are different for historical reasons? Or are they meant to be "higher-level" request methods? In the former case I would propose renaming them as they are private anyway; in the latter case I would simplify their interface so the caller doesn't need to set all of `method`, `data` and `headers` to get a working POST request

[1] http://docs.cloudstack.apache.org/en/latest/dev.html#making-api-requests
[2] https://github.com/apache/tomcat/blob/e5168242ad7600e19ac14eef87aced2cd6ab7325/java/org/apache/catalina/connector/Request.java#L3179

Thanks and sorry for the delay.

The changes look good to me so I went ahead and merged them into trunk.

When you get a chance it would also be great if you can add some documentation on how to authenticate against OpenStack based clouds using a token.

Also, since this is a bigger change, can you please also file an ICLA - https://libcloud.readthedocs.io/en/latest/development.html#contributing-bigger-changes

Looking at the latest in trunk, looks like it would still fail the tests with my changes.
https://github.com/apache/libcloud/blob/trunk/libcloud/compute/drivers/gce.py.  Line 902.  Since the super happens at the end, my changes would overwrite the extra attribute they added in.
Good catch, thanks!

I've only obfuscated the IP addresses a little, and only included the first 4 entries...
I think that should be enough to see the pattern

```
~ $ ip neighbor 
1.2.10.80 dev br0 lladdr 52:54:00:bc:f9:6c STALE
1.2.10.33 dev br0 lladdr 52:54:00:04:89:51 REACHABLE
1.2.10.97 dev br0 lladdr 52:54:00:c6:40:ec DELAY
1.2.10.40 dev br0 lladdr 52:54:00:77:1c:83 STALE

~ # arp -an
? (1.2.10.80) at 52:54:00:bc:f9:6c [ether] on br0
? (1.2.10.33) at 52:54:00:04:89:51 [ether] on br0
? (1.2.10.97) at 52:54:00:c6:40:ec [ether] on br0
? (1.2.10.40) at 52:54:00:77:1c:83 [ether] on br0
```
Looks good to me.
thanks for the contribution @relaxdiego :+1:
hey @supertom did you mean to raise this? Merges don't count as a change so there are no changesets in this PR.
Change look good. thanks for the contribution :+1:

thanks for the contribution @raittes - libcloud convention is that any arguments which are not present in the base class methods are prepending with `ex_`.
Please could you rename the parameter to ex_params.

Ideally, there would be named keyword arguments for typical arguments, according to the docs https://developer.rackspace.com/docs/cloud-load-balancers/v1/developer-guide/#list-load-balancers they would include **status**, **nodeaddress** and **changes-since**.
With a simple dictionary param, it's leaving it to the developer consuming to have to read the API documentation.
well that broke everything :fire:

Thanks a lot for this contribution!

I thought we already support SNI, but it looks like we doesn't.

Since this code touches security related code, it will need thorough reviews and also extensive tests (I see you updated existing tests which is great, but we also need additional tests coverage which cover those new changes - including all the common and edge cases).

Having said that, we are working on replacing our http layer with the `requests` library in the near feature (https://github.com/apache/libcloud/pull/728). We should decide if it's worth spending a lot more time on this change or we should instead focus on the requests change which is the future for us.

Again, thanks a lot.

Awesome, thanks.

I will look into it ASAP.

@samsong8610, Currently for Aliyun ECS, if you did not create a security group through web browser, you would encounter  'None security group' error when running example_aliyun_ecs.py to create a VM instance. So I have added the ex_create_security_group and ex_delete_security_group functions in ecs.py to solve it

Thanks for taking a look, we need SNI support pretty quickly to support some some compute platforms for our customers , which are now adopting SNI-only API endpoints, so its pretty urgent / important for us. 

The patch is really simple, it is to start using the SSLContext wrapper introduced in python 2.7. In the [security considerations](https://docs.python.org/3/library/ssl.html#ssl-security) statement, they recommend using a default context (_create_default_context_), but doing so would significantly change the behaviour of the ssl functionality today, by specifying defaults that the user didn't have before (so really, nothing has changed).

If the system is not supporting SSLContext (i.e, python 2.6), then we fall back to the previous method.

With regards to tests, can you tell me what additional coverage you need, bearing in mind the interface , which produces a wrap_socket, is practically identical? 

Also, with regards to moving to requests, that's great news, but unfortunately, we need this functionality now, and can't really wait... I hope you understand.
Cool, great contribution! LGTM :+1: for adding tests too

Thanks!

FYI, there is a breaking change to the DO block storage API coming in the next couple weeks (like I said, the feature is in beta). If you'd like to merge this now I'll submit a follow-up PR when the API change happens, or if you'd like to hold off I'll update this PR after the change.

The removed (9bf6448) code was not intentional. In fact It was another bug , and I would pull a new request to solve it.

There was still one .pyc file left (`libcloud/__init__.pyc`). I removed that and merged branch into trunk.

In the future I would recommend you to base your changes on a new and separate branch in your fork and not trunk. This will make it easier to synchronize your fork with the latest upstream version and prevent conflicts.

Thanks.

Have you seen https://github.com/certifi/python-certifi/issues/26? Is it worth adding some docs/release notes about expected behaviour with older openssl?

At conda-forge, we are using `openssl` 1.0.2 currently. Same story with `defaults`. So, if they are using a `conda` install, they should be fine.

If not, you could try using `old_where` in some places or provide some option to set that to the default.

apart from some style comments, the driver definitely needs a test suite as well as a supporting collection of fixtures from actual CLC API endpoints. Then it needs some documentation in the `docs/` folder, there are plenty of examples from other drivers.
